G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: 3. This Court has continuing jurisdiction over custody and parenting matters involving the minor children pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28 and applicable Massachusetts law, because a prior judgment concerning legal and physical custody and parenting time was issued by this Court.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 3.proposition: 4. Venue is proper in the Berkshire County Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the prior judgment was entered in this division and the parties and minor children reside within this Court’s jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 223, \u00a7 1.proposition: 4. Venue is proper in the Berkshire County Probate and Family Court under G.L. c. 215, § 3 and G.L. c. 223, § 1 because the prior judgment was entered in this division and the parties and minor children reside within this Court’s jurisdiction.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: 8. A Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting‑time judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the child.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: 8. A Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting‑time judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial custody determination and the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its impact on the child. It does not discuss the standards for modifying an existing custody or parenting‑time judgment, nor does it reference any requirement of a material and substantial change in circumstances as a prerequisite to modification. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the modification standard stated in the proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above.

Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215 (2002)
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: 8. A Probate and Family Court may modify a custody or parenting‑time judgment when there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances and modification is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the child.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion does discuss modification of support orders and quotes the general standard that modification requires a demonstrated change in circumstances, but it does so only in the context of alimony/support, not custody or parenting time. There is no analysis or holding about modifying a custody or parenting‑time judgment, nor about the standard being a material and substantial change necessary to protect and promote the child’s best interests. Therefore, the case does not support the specific proposition stated.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
In considering Joyce’s argument on appeal, we are mindful of our standard of review. As stated in Heistand v. Heistand, 384 Mass. 20, 26-27 (1981):

“In the interests of finality this court has conditioned modification upon a demonstrated change in circumstances after entry of the original decree. Robbins v. Robbins, 343 Mass. 247, 249 (1961). The determination of the extent and palpability of such change, however, lies in large measure within the discretion of the trial judge.”

Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.proposition: 9. In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child, including the child’s safety, emotional well‑being, and stability.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that in removal decisions under G.L. c. 208, § 30, the governing standard is the best interests of the child and then explains that this inquiry focuses on the effect of the proposed change on the child’s life, including the child’s emotional, physical, and developmental needs and the impact on relationships with each parent. Although framed in the context of removal rather than generic modification of custody/parenting time, the court clearly identifies the child’s best interests as the paramount consideration and details safety- and stability-related factors encompassed in that standard.
Yannas v. Frondistou\u2011Yannas, 395 Ma.relevant_excerpt: “The words ‘upon cause shown’ mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these ‘best interests’ are to be determined. … An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change … and the extent to which moving or not moving will affect the emotional, physical, or developmental needs of the child.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.proposition: 9. In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child, including the child’s safety, emotional well‑being, and stability.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.support_reasoning: The opinion expressly reaffirms that in custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10(a), the governing standard is the best interests of the child and describes that standard as the paramount concern. While this case is about an initial custody determination (not a post‑judgment modification), its discussion is broadly framed as to “custody matters” and repeatedly emphasizes welfare, stability, and continuity—i.e., safety, emotional well‑being, and stability—as central to the best‑interests analysis. Thus it substantively supports the proposition about the paramountcy of the child’s best interests in custody/parenting-time decisions.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834, 840\u201.relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… and has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt… (best interests standard ‘has long been used in Massachusetts to decide issues of custody and visitation’); Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas… (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’). … Stability is itself of enormous benefit to a child….”

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 243 (2000)
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.proposition: 9. In determining whether to modify custody or parenting time, the paramount consideration is the best interests of the child, including the child’s safety, emotional well‑being, and stability.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.support_reasoning: The opinion squarely states that custody orders under G.L. c. 209C are made on the basis of the child’s best interests, and it upholds a modification of custody based on extensive findings about the child’s welfare, including parenting quality, safety-related concerns, emotional well‑being, and stability. The court emphasizes that the judge may weigh any factors pertinent to the child’s best interests and looks to both present and probable future welfare, which encompasses safety, emotional well‑being, and stability when determining or changing custody and parenting arrangements.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. 237, 2.relevant_excerpt: “‘[C]ustody orders and judgments [including those under G. L. c. 209C] are made on the basis of a determination of the best interests of the child . . . .’ … and a judge may consider any factors found pertinent to those interests in the circumstances of the dispute. … ‘It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future . . . .’ Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 403….”

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31A.proposition: 10. Exposure of children to domestic violence, unsafe caregivers, or a household environment involving a pattern of yelling, intimidation, and physical aggression is directly relevant to the best‑interests determination and can constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification.

C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559 (1988).proposition: 10. Exposure of children to domestic violence, unsafe caregivers, or a household environment involving a pattern of yelling, intimidation, and physical aggression is directly relevant to the best‑interests determination and can constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification.
C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559 (1988).support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt is a civil procedure/statute of limitations decision about relation back of amendments to add a products-liability defendant. It does not involve child custody, best-interests standards, domestic violence, or any family-law issues. Therefore, it does not support the proposition regarding exposure of children to domestic violence as a material change for modification determinations.
C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559 (1988).relevant_excerpt: Our cases have not, however, permitted an amendment to relate back to the date of the commencement of the action when, as here, the amendment seeks to add a new defendant after the statute of limitations has run and to allege against that new defendant a theory of liability wholly different from the theory of liability of the original complaint. A proper reading of rule 15 (c) leads to the same result.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 595\u201.proposition: 10. Exposure of children to domestic violence, unsafe caregivers, or a household environment involving a pattern of yelling, intimidation, and physical aggression is directly relevant to the best‑interests determination and can constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification.

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20134.proposition: 10. Exposure of children to domestic violence, unsafe caregivers, or a household environment involving a pattern of yelling, intimidation, and physical aggression is directly relevant to the best‑interests determination and can constitute a material and substantial change warranting modification.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7\u00a7 28, 31, 31A.proposition: 11. Courts are empowered to impose conditions on parenting time, including restrictions on the presence of third parties or orders for supervised parenting time, where necessary to safeguard the welfare of the children.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u20.proposition: 11. Courts are empowered to impose conditions on parenting time, including restrictions on the presence of third parties or orders for supervised parenting time, where necessary to safeguard the welfare of the children.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u20.support_reasoning: The case squarely recognizes that a probate judge may limit or condition a noncustodial parent’s visitation, including restricting that parent’s religious instruction, where such conduct is shown to be harmful to the child’s welfare. The court reverses the specific restriction here because of inadequate proof of harm, not because such conditions are beyond judicial power; it emphasizes that limitations on visitation are permissible if supported by detailed evidence of physical or emotional injury to the child.
Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. 232, 233\u20.relevant_excerpt: But the “best interests” of the child are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds, the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents… However, harm to the child from conflicting religious instructions or practices, which would justify such a limitation, should not be simply assumed or surmised; it must be demonstrated in detail… The decisions hold such an infirmity to be fatal to an action seeking to limit materially or to cancel visitation rights.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404–05 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: 11. Courts are empowered to impose conditions on parenting time, including restrictions on the presence of third parties or orders for supervised parenting time, where necessary to safeguard the welfare of the children.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses custody and visitation in terms of reducing a father’s visitation time based on the children’s best interests, but it does not address imposing specific conditions such as barring third parties or ordering supervised parenting time. The only limitation discussed is a quantitative reduction in visitation, not qualitative restrictions or supervision. Therefore, it does not provide authority for courts imposing conditions like third‑party restrictions or supervised contact.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he “best interests” of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.proposition: 11. Courts are empowered to impose conditions on parenting time, including restrictions on the presence of third parties or orders for supervised parenting time, where necessary to safeguard the welfare of the children.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.support_reasoning: The opinion is about the constitutionality and construction of a grandparent visitation statute and the standards for ordering such visitation over parental objection. It does not address judicial authority to set conditions on a parent’s own parenting time, to restrict third-party presence during that time, or to order supervised parenting time. Because the case concerns third‑party (grandparent) visitation, not regulation of parental access or parenting conditions, it does not support the specific proposition cited.
Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 658\u2013.relevant_excerpt: "These cases recognize that disruption of a child’s preexisting relationship with a non-biological parent can be potentially harmful to the child, and they hold that such a relationship may be protected by court-ordered visitation with a nonparent over a fit parent’s objection. See E.N.O. v. L.M.M., supra at 834, 830 (concluding that judge properly allowed de facto parent’s motion for temporary visitation with child and, in considering motion, properly considered whether such visitation would be in child’s best interests); Youmans v. Ramos, 429 Mass. 774, 782-783 (1999) (concluding that judge may order visitation between child and maternal aunt who was child’s de facto parent after considering best interests of child)."

G.L. c. 209A.proposition: 17. The Cohabitant’s documented history of assault and battery and prior G.L. c. 209A restraining order reflects a pattern of violent or abusive behavior that is directly relevant to the safety of the minor children and the suitability of the Defendant’s household during parenting time.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590.proposition: 27. Accordingly, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances that justifies and necessitates modification of the Existing Judgment to protect and promote the minor children’s best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an appeal from an initial custody judgment and addresses the need for explicit findings about domestic violence and its effect on the child in determining best interests. It does not discuss post‑judgment modification standards, nor does it hold that any particular set of facts constitutes a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of an existing judgment. Therefore, it cannot be cited as authority for the proposition that a material and substantial change has occurred requiring modification of an existing custody judgment.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590.relevant_excerpt: "Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31. We do not by this decision require the judge to hear further testimony if he does not consider that necessary, but at the least he must hear both parties and make explicit findings on the matters set out above."

Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct. 215
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: 27. Accordingly, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances that justifies and necessitates modification of the Existing Judgment to protect and promote the minor children’s best interests.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion concerns valuation of a sole proprietorship, calculation of income, alleged "double dipping," and a request to modify support based on the wife’s disability. On modification, the court explicitly holds that there was not a sufficient change in circumstances to warrant increased support. It does not state that there *was* a material and substantial change justifying modification to protect children’s best interests; instead, it affirms denial of an upward modification. Thus it does not support the asserted proposition and in fact cuts the other way.
Champion v. Champion, 54 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt:
“Those findings led him to conclude that because Joyce’s net weekly income exceeded her weekly expenses by about sixteen dollars, she had failed to show a change in circumstances sufficient to justify an upward modification of the alimony order set out in the amended judgment.

…

Based upon the evidence, the findings, and the trial judge’s broad range of discretion, we must conclude that his decisions on the complaint for modification … are to stand.”

Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).proposition: 27. Accordingly, there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances that justifies and necessitates modification of the Existing Judgment to protect and promote the minor children’s best interests.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).support_reasoning: The opinion is about statutory interpretation of the Massachusetts paternity statute and the limits on a judge’s authority to order a relocating, sole legal parent to return to Massachusetts. It does not discuss standards for modification of an existing custody judgment, nor does it address what constitutes a “material and substantial change in circumstances” justifying modification. The cited language concerns the improper relocation analysis and the mother’s rights before paternity adjudication, not post‑judgment modification based on changed circumstances.
Smith v. McDonald, 458 Mass. 540 (2010).relevant_excerpt: "The court concludes, and I concur, that the judge had no authority to issue an order during the pendency of litigation for the child (and hence the mother) to move back to Massachusetts. ... As the court acknowledges, a person having sole parental rights is ‘free to move with the child wherever she wishe[s].’ ... Once it was established that the mother had relocated prior to an adjudication of paternity, the judge had no grounds to examine the reasons for or sincerity of the mother’s move."

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 842\u20134.proposition: 28. The best interests of Emily and Noah require that they be protected from exposure to domestic conflict, aggressive behavior, and individuals with recent or significant histories of violent conduct.

Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243.raw_text: Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243.proposition: 28. The best interests of Emily and Noah require that they be protected from exposure to domestic conflict, aggressive behavior, and individuals with recent or significant histories of violent conduct.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243.support_reasoning: The opinion is a general best-interests custody analysis focused on primary caretaking, parental judgment, ability to communicate, and stimulation/structure for the child. It does not articulate a principle that children’s best interests require protection from domestic conflict, aggressive behavior, or persons with violent histories. Indeed, the court notes the father’s criminal history and prior 209A orders but expressly finds no pattern of domestic violence precluding custody and affirms the award to him, which cuts against using this case as authority for the stated proposition.
Custody of Zia, 50 Mass. App. Ct. at 243.relevant_excerpt: “The mother’s challenge to the judge’s finding that ‘[t]here is no history of domestic violence perpetrated by or upon either party’ is not persuasive. The judge was aware of, and made findings concerning, the issuance of the earlier c. 209A orders. We think it apparent, on review of the findings as a whole, that the judge considered the question of abuse and was of the opinion that the present case presented no history or pattern of domestic violence that would preclude an award of custody to the father.”

C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559.proposition: 29. Massachusetts law requires the Court to give special attention to any pattern or serious incident of abuse when making custody and parenting‑time determinations, including modifications.
C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559.support_reasoning: The opinion provided is not C.O. v. M.O. at all; it is Bengar v. Clark Equipment Co., a products liability/statute of limitations/amendment case. It does not address custody, parenting time, domestic abuse, or any requirement that courts give special attention to patterns or serious incidents of abuse in custody determinations. Therefore it cannot support the stated family-law proposition.
C.O. v. M.O., 401 Mass. 559.relevant_excerpt: Massachusetts has long had a liberal policy allowing amendments which add or substitute parties after the statute of limitations has expired.... Our cases have not, however, permitted an amendment to relate back to the date of the commencement of the action when, as here, the amendment seeks to add a new defendant after the statute of limitations has run and to allege against that new defendant a theory of liability wholly different from the theory of liability of the original complaint.

Felton v. Felton, 383 Mass. at 233\u2013.proposition: 32. The Plaintiff does not seek to eliminate or unreasonably restrict the Defendant’s relationship with the minor children, but rather to place appropriate and narrowly tailored conditions on the Defendant’s parenting time so as to protect the children while preserving their bond with the Defendant.

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404–05
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. at 404.proposition: 32. The Plaintiff does not seek to eliminate or unreasonably restrict the Defendant’s relationship with the minor children, but rather to place appropriate and narrowly tailored conditions on the Defendant’s parenting time so as to protect the children while preserving their bond with the Defendant.

Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. at 658\u201360.proposition: 32. The Plaintiff does not seek to eliminate or unreasonably restrict the Defendant’s relationship with the minor children, but rather to place appropriate and narrowly tailored conditions on the Defendant’s parenting time so as to protect the children while preserving their bond with the Defendant.

Custody of Vaughn.proposition: B. Find that modification of the Existing Judgment is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the minor children, Emily Ramirez and Noah Ramirez, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A and applicable case law, including Custody of Vaughn, Custody of Kali, Smith v. McDonald, and related authorities;

Find that modification of the Existing Judgment is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the minor children, Emily Ramirez and Noah Ramirez, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A and applicable case law, including Custody of Vaughn, Custody of Kali, Smith v. McDonald, and related authorities;

Smith v. McDonald.proposition: B. Find that modification of the Existing Judgment is necessary to protect and promote the best interests of the minor children, Emily Ramirez and Noah Ramirez, pursuant to G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, 31A and applicable case law, including Custody of Vaughn, Custody of Kali, Smith v. McDonald, and related authorities;
